docs.lead_paragraph: I was 13 and walking home from school on a residential street when a car pulled over to the curb next to me. The driver, a man of about 45, leaned over and opened the passenger door and called out to me: ''I dropped my keys and can't seem to find them. Can you please help me?'' Without responding, I ran up to the nearest house and rang the doorbell. The man closed the car door and drove off. Shaken, I began to wonder what might have happened if no house had been nearby. Would he have gotten out of the car and chased me? What would I have done? What could I have done?
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on empowering children to help them thwart or resist abductors; comments on organization, Fighting Chance, and video and DVD called Give Your Kid a Fighnting Chance, which teaches children from 5 to 18 how to escape from attacker; notes that Justice Department reports that each year 69,000 children are abducted, 12,000 of them by people who are not family members; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors treating breast cancer patients often fail to use chemotherapy as frequently as federal guidelines recommend, especially when patients are older, a study reports. The older the woman is, researchers found, the less likely she is to be given the treatment. The study, in Annals of Internal Medicine, examines the use of chemotherapy in women who had tumors removed. The goal was to determine how closely doctors followed the recommendations of the National Institutes of Health. The lead author was Dr. Xianglin L. Du of the University of Texas Medical Branch at Galveston.
docs.abstract: Study finds that doctors treating breast cancer often fail to use chemotherapy as frequently as federal guidelines recommend; finds that the older the woman, the less likely she is to be given treatment (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gambling in the nation continues to rise, with 82 percent of adult Americans saying they had gambled in the last year, a study has found. The report, by the Research Institute on Addictions at the University at Buffalo, is in the winter issue of The Journal of Gambling Studies. The principal investigator was Dr. John W. Welte.
docs.abstract: Study finds that gambling in nation continues to rise, with 82 percent of adult Americans saying they had gambled in last year (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Those who have combed the Internet for mainstream medical advice have, no doubt, been barraged with far more information than they could possibly want: scientific articles and pseudoscience; anecdotes of personal triumphs and tragedies; references to books and videos; and, of course, online support groups. Few people are qualified to distinguish between the truths and half-truths that cascade from search engines or to sift hype from reality.

headline.main: Sifting Through the Online Medical Jumble

docs.abstract: Guide to online services that search for medical information (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Most people can obtain 90 to 100 percent of the vitamin D they need from a little sun. But if you are reading this in the northern two-thirds of the country, don't bother heading outside for a quick dose. (Not that we discourage a brisk daily constitutional.) Winter sunlight is inadequate for vitamin D production. You are living off what you built up from warm-weather sun and the relatively small amounts in a few foods.

headline.main: A Need That Doesn't Change With the Seasons

docs.abstract: People should see that they get enough vitamin D in winter months, when they are indoors most of time and may not get enough vitamin D from sun; map; photos; chart shows dietary sources for vitamin D (M)

headline.main: Shining a Light on the Health Benefits of Vitamin D

docs.lead_paragraph: The calls are the same. A concerned uncle or boss worries about a young person dealing with newly diagnosed M.S. and reeling from the bad news. Will I talk to them? ''Of course,'' I answer, knowing that the calls will rarely come. Talking about the disease is the last thing these neophytes really want. A hiding place is more like it. Horrific possibilities fill their imaginations and the need to know shuts down.
docs.abstract: Richard Cohen describes living with multiple sclerosis for last 30 years; praises new book The First Year--Multiple Sclerosis, by Margaret Blackstone, one in series dealing with chronic illnesses (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When she took charge of the World Health Organization four and a half years ago, Dr. Gro Harlem Brundtland was certain that she would move health issues to the top of the global agenda and leave her no-nonsense imprint on the giant, troubled agency. Known simply as Gro in Norway, the brusque physician had been a dominant force there for more than a decade -- the first woman to become prime minister and the youngest person to hold the post. Her report on sustainable development, which led to the 1992 Earth Summit, had earned her international renown.
docs.abstract: Profile of Dr Gro Harlem Brundtland, who is nearing end of her term as director-general of World Health Organization; curbing tobacco use has been one of her priorities; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors need to be much more aggressive in treating high blood pressure in people with diabetes, a new study says. Diabetics are three times as likely as the general population to have elevated readings. A separate study found that some diabetics in their late teens exhibited arterial changes associated with heart disease that are typically not found until people reach their 40's.

headline.main: For Diabetics, a Gap in Monitoring

docs.abstract: Study finds that doctors must be much more aggressive in treating high blood pressure in people with diabetes; diabetics are three times as likely as general population to have elevated readings (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fifteen percent of pregnant women surveyed as they waited in clinics for prenatal care said they had drunk alcohol during pregnancy, a new study reports. Given the evidence that alcohol use can cause birth defects, doctors should do a better job of telling women about the risks, said the study, which is in the journal Alcoholism: Clinical and Experimental Research.
docs.abstract: New study reports that 15 percent of women surveyed as they wait in clinics for prenatal care said they had drunk alcohol during pregnancy (S)
